 REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION OF THE PRESIDENT
TO THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS
ON A PROPOSED LOAN AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
TO INDIA FOR THE
GANDHAR FIELD DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

1.
I submit to the Board of Directors, for its consideration and
decision, the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan from
the ordinary capital resources (OCR) of the Bank in an amount in various
currencies equivalent to $267 million applied for by India for the Gandhar
Field Development Project. The loan will have a term of 20 years,
including a grace period of 4 years, an interest rate determined in
accordance with the Bank's pool-based variable lending rate system, and
a commitment charge of 0.75 per cent per annum. This report also
describes two technical assistance (TA) grants in a total amount of $1.07
million, applied for by the Government.

2.
In September 1990 the Government requested Bank assistance for
the proposed Project. TA was approved in November 1990 V for the purpose
of undertaking a review of the policies, operations and institutions
associated with the hydrocarbon sector. A Fact-Finding Mission visited
India in January 1991. The Appraisal Mission visited India from 8 to 28
May 1991 and confirmed the Project's priority and suitability for Bank
financing. Loan negotiations were held in Manila from 16 to 19 October
1991 with the authorized representatives of the Borrower and the
Guarantor. If approved, the proposed loan will be the Bank's seventeenth
loan to India and the second in the oil and gas sector.

I. THE ECONOMY

A Board Information Paper, "Economic Review and Bank
3.
Operations" (EBO:IND 91014), was circulated in August 1991 (IN. 163-91).

A.	

Ener gy Sector

4.
Commercial energy sources comprising coal, oil, natural gas,
hydropower and nuclear power provide about 60 per cent of the total energy
consumed in India, while noncommercial sources such as firewood, other
plant materials and biomass meet the rest of the energy demand. Between
FY1986 and FY1990, the pattern of commercial energy consumption changed,
with a small shift to natural gas and a small reduction in the percentage
share of coal in the energy mix. Coal, however, continued to be the main
fuel source in FY199O, providing about 51 per cent of primary commercial
energy consumption, followed by oil (31 per cent), natural gas (5 per
cent), hydropower (12 per cent) and nuclear power (1 per cent). Over 60
per cent of the commercial energy supply is consumed by the industry,
transport and agriculture sectors, In FY1990 the industry sector consumed
about 47 per cent; transport, 25 per cent; agriculture, 3 per cent; and

1 TA No 1416: Review of Hydrocarbon Sector Operations, for $100,000, approved

8 November 1990.

 the household sector, about 14 per cent. The balance of 11 per cent was
consumed by other sectors of the economy.

In terms of energy resource endowment, India has substantial
5.
reserves of coal, oil, natural gas and hydropower. Current known reserves
of coal and lignite are estimated at about 48.6 billion tons; oil, 558
million tons; and natural gas 500 billion cubic meters (BCM). Hydro-
electric potential is estimated at 90,000 megawatts (MW). In FY1990 India
produced 201 million tons of coal, 34 million tons of oil, 9 BCM of gas11
and 62 million kilowatt-hours of hydroelectricity. Despite these
significant increases in indigenous energy- production, the pace of
exploitation of India's domestic energy resources remains relatively low.
It is estimated that coal reserves could last over 200 years, oil reserves
about 16 years and gas about 30 years at the current rates of extraction.
The potential for proving additional reserves of oil and for increasing
gas production appears to be promising.

The scarcity of electric power, coal and natural gas supplies
6.
remains a key constraint to accelerating the rate of industrialization in
India and continues to prevent the full utilization of installed
industrial production capacity. To cover oil supply shortfalls, oil and
oil products have had to be imported in increasing quantities and at
increasing costs. Between FY1986 and FY1990, India's oil and oil product
imports increased by 17.5 per cent a year to reach 23.9 million tons,
while the cost of such imports increased annually by 3 per cent to $3.3
billion. The gap between energy demand and supply is projected by the
Government to widen to about 47 million tons of oil equivalent by the year
2000. Such shortfalls will have to be met by costly imports which will
continue to place a heavy burden on the economy. Continued efforts need
to be made by the Government to strengthen its energy strategy, to manage
demand more effectively and to augment domestic supply through appropriate
policy initiatives and investments.

B.	

Sector Policies and Strategies

In designing its energy strategy, the Government has emphasized
7.
the development of indigenous energy resources and the overcoming of
energy supply and distribution constraints. This has involved the
allocation of a large share of investible resources for the development
of hydrocarbons, the expansion of coal-based and gas-based thermal power
plants, the establishment of domestic refining capacity and the
mechanization of open cast coal mines. Budget allocations for the energy
sector in the Seventh Five-Year Plan (FY1986-FY1990) reached about $25
billion equivalent or about 29 per cent of the total Plan outlay. The
Eighth Plan which has been delayed but which is expected to cover the
period FY1993-FY1998, will likely continue energy allocations above this
level. Of the total energy allocation under the Seventh Plan, about $5.5
billion was expended on oil and gas activities (exploration, production,
infrastructure), while indications are that the Eighth Plan will provide
for an allocation of about $7.7 billion.

Inclusive of flared gas, total gas production was 17 BCM.

 tn the context of the urgent need to reduce energy shortages and
8.
relieve the pressure on the budget, the Government has been moving
increasingly over the past three to four years toward (i) ensuring full
cost recovery in the setting of prices for the energy sector;
(ii) enhanced private sector involvement in the development of the energy
sector; and (iii) increasing emphasis on energy conservation and energy
efficiency.

These strategies certainly have applicability to the oil and gas
9.
sector as well. Since the early 1970s, with the discoveries in the Bombay
High offshore field, India has been able substantially to reduce its
reliance on oil imports. However, production from this field levelled
off around 1985. The achievement of even current levels of petroleum
self-sufficiency through the l990s implies heavy investments in enhanced
oil recovery and in new exploration, accelerated development of hitherto
unexploited fields and substitution of natural gas for oil products within
the domestic energy demand mix. While Government strategies appear to
assume large additional discoveries in the next few years as well as
faster development of existing reserves, the likely investment resource
constraints suggest that efforts to provide for more efficient use of
energy and substitution of oil products with other indigenous energy
resources may provide a more likely avenue for maximizing the availability
of hydrocarbon resources in the energy sector.

C.	

External Assistance to the Oil and Gas Sector

The World Bank has provided the largest amount of external
10.
assistance to the oil and gas sector in India, with approval of 11 loans
totalling about $2.8 billion since the first loan was provided in 1977.
The most recent loan of $150 million for the Oil and Gas Sector
Development Project was made in July 1991. The World Bank has been
encouraging rapid development of the sector to replace imported petroleum
products, promoting economically based pricing policies and encouraging
the use of gas for power and industrial applications. The Bank is a more
recent participant in the sector and has been closely coordinating its
activities with those of the World Bank to achieve complementarity of
their assistance programs and a uniformity of approach on policy issues,
dialogue and conditionalities. Further aid has been provided by Canada,
Japan and France. Canada has provided lines of credit totalling about
Can$ 340 million; Japan has assisted with  V 72 billion while France has
provided F 624 million (for details see the Appendix). The Bank provided
its first assistance to the sector in the form of a Special Assistance
loan in l99lV to increase the availability of diesel fuel for industry and
transportation in the face of shortages arising from the Gulf crisis.

Loan No. 1081: Special Assistance, for $150 million, approved 4 April 1991.

II BANK OPERATIONS IN INDIA

A.	

Past Operations

11. A Board Information Paper on the Bank's operations in India
(EBO:IND 91014) was circulated to the Board of Directors in August 1991
(IN. 163-91).

B.	

Oterational Strategy

Since beginning India operations in 1986, the Bank's operational
12.
strategy has focused on the industrialization of the economy, one of the
Government's most important objectives. Bank assistance is targeted at
improving the structure of industry and making more efficient use of
productive capacity, and at easing infrastructure bottlenecks to the
growth of industry. A detailed review of the Bank's operational strategy
undertaken in 1989/1990 reconfirmed this strategy.

As a result of various developments that have taken place in the
13.
industry and transport sectors (as well as in the modernization of
agriculture), the pattern of energy consumption has changed over time
towards reliance on commercial sources. In fact, the kind of development
path chosen by India - - with its emphasis on heavy and basic industries
and on self-reliance - - has been relatively energy-intensive with respect
to commercial sources, partly in response to the inherently energy-
intensive characteristics of most heavy industries, and partly as a result
of widespread inefficiencies in energy use. Economic progress in India,
therefore, is heavily dependent on commercial energy developments. Since
the mid-l97Os the production of oil and natural gas has trebled. However,
despite increases in energy output (including electric power and coal as
well as oil and gas), shortages and variable quality of energy supply
remain widespread and this has constrained both industrial growth and
generally economic growth. If the pace of economic growth is to be
stepped up in the coming years, and if the industry sector is expected to
remain the main engine of that growth, ways have to be found to reduce
shortages and poor quality by increasing energy capacity and/or improving
efficiency in energy use. Natural gas constitutes more than 50 per cent
of India's hydrocarbon resources. However, gas development is in its
early stages, and gas resources are still very much underutilized. As a
generator of power, it is more efficient and much cleaner than coal. It
has wide applicability as an industrial feedstock (for example, in
fertilizer production). For oil, the situation is less certain; oil
production in recent years has outstripped new discoveries but has
stabilized. Hence, domestic oil supply increases in the future will
depend on the success of new exploration.

In the context of formulating the Special Assistance Proj ectV
14.
in early 1991, the Bank identified a number of oil and gas sector issues,
including pricing, private sector involvement, conservation, and
environmental protection, and began an intensive dialogue with the

Government and the Bank on the nature and scope of these issues, on

C.	

Bank Assistance to the Ener gy Sector

The Bank's program of assistance for the energy sector has, to
15.
date, involved the provision of four loans for electricity projects, 11 and
one Special Assistance Loan to finance diesel inputs in response to the
urgent needs of the 1990/1991 Gulf crisis. The Bank also sanctioned TA
to undertake a review of hydrocarbon sector operations to prepare the
groundwork for further Bank operations in the sector, including the
proposed loan, and to help support policy dialogue.

III. THE PROJECT

16.

A Report entitled "Appraisal of the Gandhar Field Development

A.	

Objectives

The main objective of the Project is to carry out the second
17.
phase of a two-phase program for development of the Gandhar field so as
to increase domestic oil and gas production and to substitute equivalent
imports. The Project will thereby assist India's industrial development
by freeing up scarce foreign exchange for imports of other needed
industrial inputs. It will provide additional petroleum-based industrial
feedstocks and fuels that are more efficient and environmentally safer
than coal. The Project is fully in conformity with the Bank's operational
strategy for India.

B

(i) drilling of oil, gas, and water and gas injection wells;

(ii) workover of wells;

C.	

Cost Estimates and Financing Plan

The total cost of the Project is estimated at $710 million
19.
equivalent (inclusive of taxes and duties). The foreign currency cost is
$321 million (45 per cent), including $37.6 million for interest and other
charges during construction; the local currency cost is $389 million
equivalent (55 per cent). The cost estimates include provisions for
physical contingencies and price escalation and have been estimated using
1991 market prices.

It is proposed that the Bank provide from its ordinary capital
20.
resources a loan of $267 million equivalent (37.6 per cent of total
Project cost) to finance a part of the foreign exchange cost of the
Project. Interest on the loan will be determined in accordance with the
Bank's pool-based variable lending rate system, with a commitment charge
of 0.75 per cent per annum. The loan will be repaid over a period of 20
years, including a grace period of 4 years. These terms take into account
the economic life of the Project facilities and equipment and the Project
implementation period. The Oil and Natural Gas Commission (ONCC) will be
the borrower of the proposed loan and India will be the Guarantor. ONGC
will bear the foreign exchange and interest rate risks. ONGC has provided
$6.4 million for foreign costs and will provide $389.0 million equivalent
for local costs. The Government and 014CC have requested the Bank to
assist in arranging commercial co-financing of $33.2 million for foreign
currency costs under the Bank's Complementary Financing Scheme. In the
event that commercial co-financing is unavailable, ONGC has given
assurance that it will provide funds from its own resources. The World
Bank has already financed initial equipment and material costs under the
Project costing $14.4 million out of the loan savings under its ongoing
Western Gas Development Project (see Appendix).

 D.	

Executing Agency

(1) History and Organization

21.
The ONGC will be the Executing Agency for the Project. ONGC,
which comes under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Petroleum and
Natural Gas (MPNG), is a wholly Government-owned statutory body. It was
established under the Oil and atura1 Gas Commission Act of 1959 to plan,
promote, organize and implement programs for the development of oil and
natural gas resources and the production and sale of oil and natural gas
products. It began commercial operations in 1960. With a total staff of
48,000 including 12,000 engineers, geoscientists and technical officers,
it has gained substantial experience and expertise since its inception,
including the management of four World Bank-financed projects. ONCC is
managed by a Commission made up ofa Chairman, six full-time Members from
within the organization and two part-time Members from outside the
organization to represent the interests of other Government agencies. The
Commission sets its own policies, carries out its own operations and
prepares its own capital investments. It has the authority to sanction
projects up to a value of Rs 500 million (about $19 million equivalent).
It has six regional centers, all of which are managed as profit centers
of their own. In addition, it has eight management and research
institutes, which carry out work in such fields as reservoir studies, oil
and gas production technology, safety and environment management,
geotechnics, drilling technology and management development.

The ONGC recognizes the need to assess its corporate strategy
22.
to ensure that it can sustain rapid growth without suffering the
diseconomies of size, and continue to improve its efficiency. ONGC has
agreed to prepare by March 1992 a plan for commercial operations for
discussion with the Bank. The plan will provide for, inter alia, greater
autonomy for the regional centers, disengaging ONGC from activities that
are more suitable for the private sector and setting up a cell within ONGC
to promote private sector involvement in the development of oil and gas
fields belonging tp ONGC. The Government has also recently reached a
decision to allow national companies such as ONGC to enter into joint
ventures for development of their existing oil fields. ONGC has already
successfully completed four substantial projects financed by the World
Bank, and has.done so with minimum delay. ONGC is a mature organization
and has become one of the larger, more profitable public enterprises in
India. It is accordingly deemed to be a suitable executing agency for
this Project.

(2) Financial Performance

The ONGC enjoys sound financial health and shows a continuing
23.
strong financial performance. ONGC benefits in this regard from
Government pricing and taxation policies, which provide adequate operating
margins for oil and gas producers. In FY1991 ONCC earned a net income of
Rs 8,7 billion (about $335 million). In recent years the price at the
wellhead, which is set by the Government in rupee terms, has declined in
dollar terms from a high of $19 per barrel in FY1987 to $12 per barrel
currently; mainly because of the recent substantial devaluation of the
rupee. Despite the devaluation and increasing taxes on wellhead prices,

 3

ONGC has been consistently able to finance all of its Local capital.
requirements from internal. cash generation. However, Or'GC's rate of
return declined from 68.1 per cent in FY1987 to 29.5 per cent in FY1991
because of rising operating expenses in the face of fixed prices for oil
and gas (in rupee terms). Also, ONGC has substantially increased Long-
term foreign borrowings over the past few years, and by the end of VY1991
will bear the foreign exchange risk on about 80 per cent of its long-term
debt of Rs 67 billion (about $2.6 billion).

24. During the period FY1987-FYl99l ONCC's annual returns on net
fixed assets ranged from 29.5 to 68.1 per cent, self-financing ratios were
65-122 per cent, and debt-service ratios were 1.5-5.4 (times). Similarly,
projections for FY1992-F'Y1995 indicate returns on net fixed assets ranging
from 19.8-25.8 per cent, self-financing ratios from 35 to 65 per cent and
debt-service ratios from 1.9 to 2.8 (times). These projections have been
prepared based on the following assumptions: (i) ONGC's annual oil and
gas production will increase to 43.5 million tons and 20.5 BCM,
respectively by FY1995; (ii) the gas price will increase by Rs 100 per
1,000 cubic meters for FY1993 and FY1994; and (iii) ONGC will incur
capital expenditures of Rs 240 billion (about $9.2 billion) over the next
four years, of which 50 per cent is envisaged to be in foreign currency.
These projections indicate that ONGC's financial position will remain
financially sound. Over the next five years, ONGC's foreign currency
requirements will be substantial, estimated at $8.4 billion. In the
immediate future, the biggest challenge facing ONCC is to secure the
necessary foreign exchange financing for its high priority projects.
Given India's present balance-of-payments and debt-service situation, ONOC
will have to increasingly devote its efforts toward securing assistance
from multilateral and bilateral sources as well as suppliers and export
credit agencies to raise the required foreign exchange to finance its
projects. For the next several years, it may be difficult for ONGC to
raise the required foreign exchange from the international commercial
markets on its own.

25. To ensure its continued sound financial performance, ONCC has
agreed to maintain at all times a debt-service ratio of not less than
1.5:1, a debt/equity ratio of not higher than 60:40 and self-financing
ratio of not less than 35 per cent for FY1992-FY1994 inclusive and not
less than 40 per cent from FY1995 onward.

E.	

Implementation

The Project is expected to be implemented over a four-year
26.	
period with scheduled completion by 31 March 1995. ONGC has already
established a Project Office headed by a Project Manager. Other senior
officials of the Project Office include a financial manager, a materials
manager and two project engineers. The Project Office will be responsible
for the financial, technical and administrative control of the Project and
its proper execution.

F.	

Procurement

Procurement of equipment and materials financed by the Bank will
27.	
be undertaken in accordance with the Bank's Guidelines for Procurement and

 9

will be on the basis of either international competitive bidding (ICB) or
international shopping, depending on contract size. Contract services
for drilling and workover to be financed under the Bank Loan will be
procured through ICB among firms providing such specialized services.
The surface utility and offsite facilities will he procured on a turnkey
basis in accordance with LCB procedures. Each bidder for such contracts
will be asked to provide detailed design and equipment to carry our
construction .mnd commissioning of the facilities and to furnish a
guarantee of performance. The items being financed through Local currency
funds under the Project will be procured through ONGC's local competitive
bidding procedures. Advance procurement and retroactive financing have
previously been approved in relation to drilling and production equipment
and for hiring of rigs for drilling and workover.

C.	

Consultants and Training

(1) Consultants

28. International consultants with expertise in corrosion
engineering, horizontal well drilling, production engineering, and water
and gas injection operation will be required to assist ONGC to ensure that
the Gandhar field is developed and managed in an optimal manner. These
consultants will be recruited by QNGC in accordance with the Bank's
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The Danish Government is
considering grant financing of about $1.0 million to finance these
consulting services. In the event such financing materializes, then the
appropriate portion of the Bank loan will be cancelled at the request of
India. ONGC has engaged domestic engineering consultants to carry out
detailed engineering design and preparation of the bidding documents for
the formation water treatment plant and the surface, utility and offsite
facilities, and to assist it in the evaluation of bids and supervision of
the construction and commissioning of these facilities. The cost of such
services will be borne by ONGC. The Mission has examined the engineering
arrangements and is satisfied that the selected domestic consultant has
the experience and.capability to perform such services.

(2) Training

29. The ONGC proposes to train its personnel for the Project in
overseas facilities employing similar technologies for oil and gas
production, and in India by engaging trainers to conduct relevant courses
and seminars. The overseas training will be for engineers, middle
managers and higher level staff and will cover a number of areas including
management, technical, procurement, environmental and safety activities.
ONGC will make suitable arrangements for return of staff to work at ONGC
after training abroad. The Danish Government may be prepared to provide
grant financing of about $1.5 million for this training program. In the
event that such financing materializes, the appropriate portion of the
Bank loan will be cancelled at the request of India.

accounts and related financial statements will be furnished to the Bank
within six months, and audited accounts within nine months of the end of
each fiscal year. A Project completion report will be submitted within
six months of Project completion.

I.	

Maintenance of Project Facilities

31. The ONGC will be responsible for the operation and maintenance
of Project facilities. Given its long experience in this regard, no
particular difficulties are foreseen.

J.	

Environment and Energy

An environment impact assessment (EIA) for the Project was
32.
completed by the National Environment Engineering Research Institute of
India, which has examined all the proposed arrangements for treatment and
disposal of solid wastes, liquid effluents and gaseous emissions. Based
on this EIA, the Project was approved by the Gujarat Pollution Control
Commission in August 1990 and by the Department of Environment and Forests
at the federal level in January 1991. The arrangement for handling solid
wastes, liquid effluents and gaseous emissions from the Project has been
found satisfactory by the Bank. Solid wastes will be used for land
filling and erection of flood control bunds to protect the wells.
Formation water effluents will be reinjected into the wells to maintain
well pressure in accordance with international petroleum industry
standards in this regard. Gaseous emissions will be flared and, since
gases produced from the Gandhar field contain less than 3 per cent carbon
dioxide and only trace amounts of sulfur, there will be no significant
environmental impact from this procedure. To continually improve the
environmental and safety management of its activities, ONGC has requested
TA for this purpose (para. 43(1)).

As regards energy issues, the Project facilities will utilize
33.
up-to-date techniques and will be designed to operate with high energy
efficiency and produce substantial energy savings. The energy from the
high-pressure oil and gas in the wells will be used to deliver the oil and
gas through the processing facilities and then to storage or to end-
consumers without the use of process pumps for oil and with relatively low
compression for gas.

K.

34.	
following specific assurances have been obtained:

In addition to the standard provisions and loan covenants, the

(i) The Government will periodically review the existing oil pricing
system and adjust the overall prices of oil products from time
to time to achieve full cost recovery from the end-consumers and
to reflect international prices at the consumer level, to allow
the operating entities to operate on a sound financial basis and
to mobilize adequate resources from the oil and gas sector.

 11

(ii) The Government will continue to aim for full fuel oil parity
and to provide an adequate return for producers, in setting gas
prices.

(iii) The Government will undertake its program of regular exploration

offerings in the future.

(iv) ONGC will prepare by March 1992 a plan for commercialization and

(v) ONGC will maintain satisfactory debt/equity and debt-service and

(vi) ONGC will ensure that (a) that all Project facilities will be

L.	

Policy Aspects

The main issue relating to the energy sector is the widening gap
35.
between energy supply and demand. Until recent years, the Government's
strategy for dealing with this fundamental problem was to encourage the
increasing development of indigenous supply. This involved the allocation
of a large share of investible resources to the development of
hydrocarbons, the expansion of oil-based and gas-based thermal power
plants, the establishment of a domestic refining capacity and the
mechanization of open-cast coal mines. Faced with energy demand shortages
and budgetary constraints, the Government has increasingly pursued other
options, including (i) adoption of suitable pricing policies for the
energy sector, (ii) enhanced private sector involvement in the energy
sector, and (iii) increasing emphasis on energy conservation and energy
efficiency.

(i) Pricing

Oil prices are set by the Government with a view to recovery of
36.
supply costs from consumers, providing an adequate return to producers to
enable them to maintain financial viability, and mobilizing resources for
the economy. Domestic prices of oil products have therefore been kept
substantially above world prices. Increased costs have been quickly
passed along to end-consumers; this was particularly evident in 1990 and
1991 when oil product prices were subject to major increases mainly in
response to the Gulf crisis and to the substantial devaluation of the
rupee in July 1991. As far as producer prices are concerned, the two main
producers, ONGC and Oil India Limited (OIL), have recently seen an erosion
of their margins. These entities are paid at fixed prices in rupee terms
(currently set at Rs 2,235 per ton). The price in dollar terms has
declined from $19 per barrel equivalent in FY1986 to $12 per barrel
currently because of the fall of rupee over the past several years and its
recent sharp depreciation. The net price retained by the producers is now

 12

about $5.3 per barrel as against production costs of about $2 (Gandhar
Field). This is still deemed to he reasonable and does not yet adversely
affect the financial position of ONGC or OIL. However, the Government has
set up an Oil Pricing Review Committee to review the net margins of oil
producers, refiners and marketers and will submit recommendations by March
1992. The Bank will he allowed to provide prior views on these
recommendations and will continue a dialogue with the Indian authorities
on these issues. As regards gas, it was historically provided to
consumers on a cost-plus basis, but in response to large finds in recent
years, the Government has sought to apply replacement pricing. To assist
in implementing new pricing regimes the Government created a Gas Pricing
Committee (Kelkar Committee) in 1988 to recommend appropriate pricing
policies, and the committee made its recommendations, which were adopted
by the Government, in May 1991 for implementation by July 1991.
Basically, the recommendations provide for producer prices to be based on
long-run average production costs from certain domestic fields sufficient
to enable producers to earn a 15 per cent rate of return on investment
after recommended price increases are implemented. Consumer prices are
to be based on the economic supply cost of marginal replacement fuel. The
difference between consumer and producer prices is to be credited to a gas
pool account maintained by MPNG and used to assist the development of gas
supply infrastructure. The Bank will continue dialogue with the
Government on gas pricing to encourage movement towards a mechanism
whereby prices would be differentiated by category of consumer in relation
to alternative fuels displaced (such as kerosene for households and diesel
for commercial users).

(ii) Private Sector Involvement

As regards the role of the private sector, the Government
37.
recognizes that the public sector alone cannot undertake and finance all
the investments needed for the accelerated development of the energy
sector. The Government has therefore begun to systematically encourage
additional private sector involvement in the oil and gas industry (and in
the power sector as well) not only to bridge the resource gap but also to
obtain appropriate technology for the accelerated development of the
sector. Over the past few years, private sector companies have become
increasingly involved in providing goods and services to the oil and gas
industry and in participating in joint ventures to supply technical oil
field services and equipment. There has also been an emphasis by the
Government on reducing its formerly exclusive role in financing capital
investments in the oil and gas industry. For example, ONGC has reduced
rig acquisition programs by about 50 per cent in favor of hiring drilling
rigs from the private sector. At present about 70 per cent of well
services in offshore areas and 30 per cent in onshore areas are performed
by private sector companies. The value of private sector services
contracted by ONGC rose from $48.8 million in F'Y1981 to over $380 million
in FY199O. Recently the Government has decided to allow ONGC to enter
into joint-ventures for the development of its existing fields and
modalities are currently being worked out by ONGC.

38.
With regard to oil and gas exploration and production, the
Government had through May 1991 made three rounds of exploration offerings
to the private sector with increasingly improved terms and conditions to

 13

ensure a favorable response. By the third round the terms and conditions
were found to be competitive with those offered by other countries with
similar prospects for oil and gas discovery. The Government announced in
July 1991 a fourth round of exploration offerings with incentives
sufficient to attract substantial interest from the private sector. The
Government has also assured that (i) it intends to continue its program
of regular exploration offerings in the future, (ii) oil produced by
private companies will be purchased at prevailing international prices,
(iii) gas produced by the private sector will be purchased at prices that
ensure full cost recovery plus an adequate return to the producers and
will be equal to but not exceeding that available to public sector
companies. In another area, the Government has indicated that it will
extend the use of open competitive bidding procedures to enable private
sector companies to acquire urban gas distribution franchises. In the
case of refineries, the Government has decided, whenever feasible, not to
commit public funds for the full financing of new refineries, but rather
to seek joint-venture private partners to develop new refinery projects.

(iii) Energy Conservation

As part of the Government's strategy to minimize the energy
39.
supply/demand gap, increasing emphasis has been placed on energy
conservation. The most important recent initiative in this regard was the
preparation in 1991 of an Action Plan on Energy Conservation (APENCON)
designed to accomplish the following: (i) prepare energy audits,
throughout the country, of heat-generating equipment (boilers, furnaces,
kilns) for the private sector and public sector and for thermal power
plants with capacities exceeding 20 MW; (ii) strengthen local institutes
and private sector consulting firms engaged in energy conservation work;
(iii) introduce appropriate regulations for mandatory energy audits and
energy-use reporting; (iv) prepare a plan to support marketing of energy-
efficient heating equipment and electrical appliances; and (v) set up
energy conservation funds or other financing facilities in various
development finance institutions. APENCON specifies targets and
objectives, firms up appropriate implementation arrangements and provides
an estimate of the resource requirements for the completion of all covered
activities. The Government provided APENCON to the Bank in July 1991.
This is now being examined by the Bank to assess the areas where the Bank
could assist the Government in implementing appropriate energy
conservation programs. In addition to APENCON, the Government plans to
implement (1) industrial energy efficiency and modernization projects to
conserve energy and improve efficiency in the highly energy-intensive
industry sector, (ii) refinery energy conservation projects to improve
the efficient use of energy in the refineries, and (iii) gas flaring
reduction projects to eliminate flaring of gas from existing fields. The
Bank is already considering proposals for assistance under its future
program in all three areas.

All of the above strategies and policies have been included in
40.
a statement on Government Policies and Strategies (GPS) in the energy
sector, which was provided by the Government to the Bank in February 1991
in the course of processing the Special Assistance Project (see footnote,
page 4). This comprehensive policy framework demonstrates the
Government's commitment to achieve full cost recovery in the pricing of

 14

energy and to enhance private sector involvement in the energy sector,
and highlights the priority attached by the Government to pursuing an
energy conservation program. it has helped to consolidate initiatives
taken from time to time in recent years in the energy sector.
Formalization of these initiatives in a policy framework outlined in the
GPS has reconfirmed their direction, strengthened their content and
minimized the risk of reversal. These developments will provide a more
satisfactory and assured environment for rapid growth and efficient
operation of the energy sector. The Government has agreed under the
Special Assistance Loan to implement the measures outlined in the  GPS and
to keep the Bank informed from time to time concerning the progress it has
made toward implementing those measures. To date the Government has
implemented the three time-bound measures provided in that GPS, including
the recommendations of the Gas Pricing Committee, announcing the fourth
round of exploration offerings and preparing the APENCON.

M.	

Project Justification and Benefits

41. Amajor constraint on industrial development in India has been
the persistent supply/demand gap for commercial energy (including power).
The Project will help to ease this critical supply/demand gap for
commercial energy and thereby help to promote further industrial and
overall economic growth and development. It supports the Government's
strategy of increasing the indigenous energy supply. It will help to
reduce the nation's dependence on oil imports and will save, on average,
about $148 million annually in foreign exchange during its 16-year
economic life. The Project will also create about 2,000 jobs during
implementation and around 500 permanent jobs when in full operation. The
financial internal rate of return (FIRR) (after tax) is estimated at 14.0
per cent, which is considered satisfactory for projects of this type. The
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) is estimated at 51.6 per cent.
Sensitivity analysis indicates that the Project will remain viable under
adverse conditions. Under the most adverse scenario, i.e., 20 per cent
decrease in production, 20 per cent decrease in prices, 20 per cent
increase in capital and operation and maintenance costs, two year delay
in Project implementation and 10 per cent increase in the depletion
premium, the EIRR remains at 32 per cent. Similarly, under the most
adverse situation, sensitivity tests show that the FIRR remains
financially sound at 6 per cent in real terms.

N.	

Project Risks

42. In the drilling and production of oil and gas, there is always
a technical risk. The Project is aimed at developing proven reserves from
a field that already contains a large number of wells, which helps to
confirm the extent of the reserves and to increase the accuracy of
estimating them. The field has already had a relatively good, although
brief, history of production, with no substantial differences between
actual and forecast rates of production. However, because of the
complexity of the reservoir, since the field is an oil, condensate and gas
field, recovery and production of hydrocarbons could fall below
expectations if the reservoir is not developed and managed efficiently.
Such risks will be minimized, however, through the provision of
consultancy inputs and staff training to help ONCC continually optimize

 15

the development and operation of the field. As regards safety risks, the
Project could be subject to fire and explosion hazards during drilling
and production of oil and gas from the field. However, such risks are
considered relatively small, because the Project facilities are designed
to meet industry safety standards, and staff of the Executing Agency will
be trained under the Project to operate and maintain the facilities safely
and efficiently. Implementation delays could result from inadequate
project management. However, the Project team has already acquired a
substantial amount of experience in implementing Phase 1 of the Gandhar
field under the World Bank-financed Western Gas Development Project (see
Annex). The training to be provided to the staff of the Executing Agency,
the planned effort on the part of Bank staff in Project monitoring and
supervision, and the hiring of additional private sector rigs by ONGC if
need be to speed up drilling will all contribute toward minimizing delays
in Project implementation. Further, the Project will be reviewed monthly
by the Regional Director of the Western Region. In addition, the existing
Executive Committee Production Monitoring Team headed by the Chairman of
ONGC will review monthly, among other things, the progress of the Project.
Marketing risks are also minimal since users of oil have been identified
and are readily available. Either gas-users already exist or new gas-
user facilities are planned or under construction. Delays in completing
new facilities can be minimized, since free gas production can be cut back
and more gas allocated to existing consumers.
